Award.AwardTitle: CI-P: Planning for Scalable Language Resource Creation through Novel Incentives and Crowdsourcing

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Advances in human language technologies enable systems that, for example, obey natural language commands and respond in kind, translate among many language pairs and summarize multilingual news. However, the technology's potential remains largely untapped because the linguistic resources that fuel development still fall far short of need. This community infrastructure planning (CI-P) initiative begins the process of building infrastructure to continuously develop high quality language resources, by employing techniques proven to work in multiple scientific disciplines. Social media, crowd-sourcing, games with a purpose and citizen science show us that human resources are effectively limitless for some activities. By offering human contributors appropriate opportunities and incentives, this project enhances language resource development well beyond what direct funding alone can produce. By removing constraints on participation, designing activities to appeal to multiple communities the project creates educational opportunities for the public including students and under-represented groups. The increase in scale and diversity of data also benefits those working in language related research, education and technology development. The availability of an ever-growing body of resources for an expanding range of languages will permit developers to supply technologies to a greater proportion of the world.

This project is the first step in the creation of infrastructure capable of high volume, continuous collection of language data and judgments through: ubiquity, perseverance, comprehensive annotation, automated training and certification, appropriate incentives, task engineering and variants of crowdsourcing. Building upon Linguistic Data Consortium's WebAnn framework, virtual front end web servers provide multiple interfaces to incentivize and engineer linguistic data contributions from targeted groups: linguists, citizen scientists, game players and students. Collection and annotation activities are analyzed into component tasks according to the skills they require and are assigned as appropriate to different workforces using different workflows. The combination of customized interfaces and novel incentive strategies enables ongoing, scalable data collection and annotation resulting in diverse language resources available to the wider Computer and Information Science and Engineering research and education communities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research, education and technology development in human language technologies is intensively data-centric. It relies upon multiple types of large scale, high quality language resources in an ever increasing variety of languages. Despite significant investment in such language resources, supply not only fails to satisfy demand but in fact loses ground every year as new technologies emerge and as new populations recognize their value and want them for new languages. Just seven years ago it was hard to interacting with a smart-phone based digital assistant (e.g. Siri) in any language, even English. However, in the intervening time, Siri has also learned to speak and respond to speech in Arabic, Chinese (Cantonese and Mandarin), Danish, Dutch, Finnish, French, German, Hebrew, Italian, Japanese, Korean, Malay, Norwegian, Portuguese, Russian, Spanish, Swedish, Thai and Turkish. Although that list is impressive, it omits thousands of the world’s language, hundreds of which are spoken by billions of people collectively and control a significant portion of the world’s wealth.

To enable the creation of human language technologies for the world’s languages, we must build infrastructure that improves, by several orders of magnitude, the rate, size quality and cost of language resource development. Our proposal is to employ techniques proven to work in multiple scientific disciplines and industry. Social media, games with a purpose and citizen science have shown that human resources are effectively limitless for some activities given appropriate incentives. By offering human contributors sustained access to opportunities that include such incentives, we will transform language resource development through people-power.

The principal purpose of this Infrastructure Planning (NSF CRI CI-P) grant was to further develop plans and partnerships in preparation of an Infrastructure Development (NSF CRI CI-NEW) proposal. Specifically we were to hold a planning workshop to include leading researchers in fields related to our initiative. Knowing that the most relevant work is emerging from a number of independent research communities, we also planned to supplement our workshop with additional meetings and with written surveys.

In October, 2016 we hosted a two-day workshop to identify challenges in applying human computation and novel incentives to the tasks of linguistic data collection and to bring together researchers and professionals from different scientific fields and disciplines who are united by similar challenges. The workshop brought together ~25 participants representing multiple research areas: linguistics, computational linguistics, data collection, computer science, Human-Computer Interaction, the humanities, and library science who shared a common interest in crowdsourcing and novel incentives. We have since scheduled seven small group meetings with more than 25 researchers who were unable to attend the workshop. We have also given multiple presentations at related conferences, workshops and scientific advisory board (SAB) meetings to promote the effort.

Through these meetings we have identified key researchers and built relationships among them in order to form a community, identified potential collaborations and in particular the infrastructure needed to support such collaborations. We have submitted the follow-on proposal which was favorable reviewed and funded and nearing the end of its first year. We have also formed an Advisory Board to guide our future efforts. Although one does not normally expect a planning grant to afford many training opportunities, we were fortunate to hire a new manager specializing in atypical projects during this effort and train him in proposal and report writing, project management, and the development of web prototypes. Our webpages at: https://www.ldc.upenn.edu/collaborations/current-projects/nieuw and https://www.ldc.upenn.edu/communications/workshops/nieuw-workshop provide background information on the project, rationale for the workshop, and a schedule of the research presentations including papers and slides where available.

Although, again, one does not normally expect many broader impacts from a planning grant, though our workshops, meetings, presentations, papers and demonstrations, we have already begun the work of recruiting multiple groups of contributors to the work of liberating the world’s languages from digital obscurity.
